ERSmeta Description: Name of the software.
OEPFF Description: What is the full model name?

ERSmeta Description: Abbreviation of the software name.
OEPFF Description: What is the abbreviation?

ERSmeta Description: The identifier property represents any kind of identifier for any kind of Thing, such as DOI, ISBNs, GTIN codes, UUIDs etc.
Link to the logo of the software.
OEPFF Description: If a logo for the model exists load it up

ERSmeta Description: Version of the software instance as used by the developers.
The computer programming language in which the software is written.
Language used within the software (e.g. variables, documentation). Standard: IETF (BCP47)
A one-line summary of what the software does.
A description of the software. Max 200 words.
Keywords or tags used to describe this software.
Graphical overview on the functionality of the software.
Research domain for which the software was written.
Research category for which the software was written.
Type of software application, e.g. 'script'.
Kind of tasks that the software tasks over in research.
Homepage of the tool. URL of the item.
OEPFF Description: If a website for the model exists please put the link here

ERSmeta Description: Description of development status, e.g. Active, inactive, suspended. See repostatus.org
Structure of the development team.
How often is the software updated?
Link to software bug reporting or issue tracking system
Any academic publication which describes the software.

A reference to another work that should be cited instead of the software or dataset itself. Note that the principles of  software citation and data citation require that software should be cited on the same basis as any other research product such as a paper or a book. Adding a different preferred citation may result in a violation of the respective primary principle, Importance, when others cite this work.
OEPFF Description: Are publications available about the framework? Please list!

ERSmeta Description: A license document that applies to this software.
The party holding the legal copyright to the CreativeWork.
A flag to signal that the software is accessible for free.
OEPFF Description: Is the framework published under an open source license?

ERSmeta Description: Typical cost for licensing the software, if available.
The date on which the software was initially created.
OEPFF Description: When [YYYY-MM-DD] was the framework initially released?

ERSmeta Description: The date on which the software was most recently modified.
A person who has contributed to the software.
A person who has authored the software.
Individual responsible for maintaining the software.
OEPFF Description: Who is the main contact person?

ERSmeta Description: Institution which developed the software.
OEPFF Description: Which institutions develop(ed}, the model?

ERSmeta Description: Country where the software was developed. Country codes as defined by ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 should be used.
Information on the funding which was used to develop the software.
If the file can be downloaded, URL to download the binary.
Link to the repository where the un-compiled, human readable code and related code is located (SVN, GitHub, CodePlex, institutional GitLab instance, etc.).
OEPFF Description: What is the link to the source code?

ERSmeta Description: Link to the documentation describing the code and is usful for developers.
OEPFF Description: Is an user documentation available for the framework? Please insert the link

ERSmeta Description: Link to software readme file.
Link to installation instructions/documentation.
OEPFF Description: Is an installation guide availaibe for the framework? Please insert the link!

ERSmeta Description: Is support for the software provided?
How long would a researcher need to be able to use the software?
Code examples for using the software.
Ways how the software developers interact with the software users (community).
OEPFF Description: What kind of support is available? Please check the boxes!

ERSmeta Description: A publication which uses the software for its research.
Description of the output functions of the software (e.g., APIs)
Description of the input functions of the software (e.g., APIs)
A software which can directly be used with the software without further changes.
OEPFF Description: Which interfaces to recommended, additional,  useful software is provided by the framework? Please list!

ERSmeta Description: Hardware which is compatible to this software (e.g., in labs).
Data which is compatible to this software.
Data that is directly used by the provided software
A general goal/purpose of the software.
An used method in the software.
OEPFF Description: What underlying methodology is the framework based on?

ERSmeta Description: A supported sector of the software. A sector is generically dependent continuant that is a subdivision of a system.
OEPFF Description: What sectoral scope was modelled with the framework?

ERSmeta Description: A supported energy technology of the software.
OEPFF Description: Which renewable energy technologies are already modelled with the framework?

ERSmeta Description: A required assumption of the software.
Other supported use case, e.g., a research question which can be answered with the software besides the main goal.
OEPFF Description: What is/are the specific purpose(s) of the framework?

ERSmeta Description: A component of the energy system included in the software.
A limitation of the software.
A relevant internal parameter of the software.
A feature of the software.
Supported temporal resolution of the software. Temporal resolution is the resolution that indicates time-dependent the level of detail.
OEPFF Description: What is/are the commonly used time step that are already modelled with the framework?

ERSmeta Description: Time scope the software was developed for (e.g. 2010, 2050).
OEPFF Description: What is/are the commonly used time horizon that are already modelled with the framework?

ERSmeta Description: Does the software support stationary or transient effects?
Supported spatial resolution of the software. Spatial resolution is the resolution that indicates the geographical level of detail.
Supported dimensions of the software.
Geo scope the software was developed for (e.g., microgrid, Germany, Europe).
OEPFF Description: What geographical scope was modelled with the framework?

ERSmeta Description: Regions covered by the model. Leave this blank if the model and data are not limited to a specific region. Examples include: USA, Canada, Germany, western Europe.
Supported voltage level of the software.
Information on an optimization included in the software.
A review of the software.
Information on the tests of the software.
Information on validations done for the software. Validation refers to whether the software produces results that correspond to real-world properties.
Typical minimal hardware which is required to run the software.
Typical execution time of the software.
Processor architecture required to run the application (e.g. IA64).
Minimum memory requirements.
Storage requirements (free space required).
What kind of realtime simulations are supported by the software?
Does the software support parallization?
Target programming enviroments to which the code applies. If applies to several versions, just the product name can be used.
OEPFF Description: Which programming language/framework is used to develop the framework?

ERSmeta Description: Operating systems supported (Windows 7, OSX 10.6, Android 1.6).
Required software dependencies.
Size of the application / package (e.g. 18MB). In the absence of a unit (MB, KB etc.), KB will be assumed.
The type and version number of the metadata.
The license of the provided metadata.

Indicates the party responsible for generating and publishing the current structured data markup, typically in cases where the structured data is derived automatically from existing published content but published on a different site. For example, student projects and open data initiatives often re-publish existing content with more explicitly structured metadata. The sdPublisher property helps make such practices more explicit.
